_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FEDERAL
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
E&J GALLO WINERY - FRESNO
JUNE 2004
 
     The E & J Gallo Fresno Winery is located at 5610 East Olive Avenue in Fresno, California.  The facility crushes grapes in order to produce wine, distilled spirits, and juice for concentrate.  These products are stored prior to shipment to other Gallo facilities for further processing and distribution.  
                                                                                                                                                                                               The facility operates anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems to provide product cooling.  Refrigeration systems have storage vessels (receivers) sized to contain all the liquid ammonia in the system, with additional capacity for thermal expansion.
 
     The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop heat transfer system.  Ammonia moves through the system due to pressure differences produced by the compressors.  A brief description of the ammonia refrigeration cycle follows:
 
1.  The receiver vessel stores liquid ammonia under pressure.  High pressure liquid ammonia flows from the receiver through liquid lines to the expansion valve, which partitions the pressure and temperature.  Liquid ammonia at reduced pressure and temperature is then piped in to the chiller shell.  
 
2.  Product is circulated through sealed stainless steel tubing within the chiller shell.  Heat from the warm product transfers through the tubing walls to the cooler refrigerant, causing liquid refrigerant to boil off as low pressure vapor.  The rate of vaporization, and thereby the cooling of product, is determined by the amount of pressure in the chiller as controlled by a back pressure regulator, and suction from the compressors.  
 
3.  The compressors draw the low pressure vapor from the chiller, compress it into high pressure vapor, and discharge it to the evaporative condenser (cooling tower).
 
4.  In the eva

porative condenser, ammonia vapor flows through tubing which is sprayed with water and located within fan driven air flow to promote cooling.  The ammonia vapor transfers heat through the tubing walls to the cooling water.  The ammonia condenses back to a liquid which drains by gravity to the receiver vessel.  
 
     In addition to ammonia refrigeration systems, the facility uses anhydrous ammonia to adjust the pH of process water being discharged to the Fresno POTW.
 

     Ammonia Systems (Processes) A? Federal RMP Program Level 3:
 
     Ammonia Supply Tank at Main Wastewater Sump
         Capacity 10,060 gal x 80% = 8048 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 41,447 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration system #1
         Capacity 2829 gal x 80% = 2263 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 11,655 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration System #2 
         Capacity 2851 gal x 80% = 2281 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal.  = 11,746 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration System #3
         Capacity 3000 gal x 80% = 2400 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 12,360 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration Systems #8, 9, 10 & 11
         Capacity 4808 gal x 80% = 3846 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 19,809 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration Systems #13 & 16
         Capacity 5839 gal x 80% = 4671 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 24,057 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration Systems #14 & 15
         Capacity 6020 gal x 80% = 4816 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 24,802 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration Systems #17 
         Capacity 3023 gal x 80% = 2418 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 12,455 lbs.
 
     Refrigeration System #18
         Capacity 3010 gal x 80% = 2408 gal x 5.15 lbs./gal. = 12,401 lbs.
 
 
 
FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY FOR RMP COVERED PROCESSES
 

     The following statements apply to the listed regulated substances held in processes covered by the Federal Risk Management Program. 
 

Ammonia
 
     In the five year period prior to this submission, the E & J Gallo Winery has not experienced any ammonia release.
 
 
 
TOXIC WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO
 
Ammonia
 
     The worst case scenario would involve the ammonia storage tan

k used to adjust the pH of wastewater.  The toxic endpoint distance is 2.6 miles.
 
 
 
TOXIC ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
 
Ammonia
 
     An alternative release scenario would involve damage to liquid ammonia piping at a chiller due to contact from motorized equipment operating in the area.  If damage was sufficient to cause a failure, it could occur at a flange due to bolt failure, and result in a 1 inch square opening.  The release of liquid ammonia from the opening could be expelled in to the air and onto the surrounding surfaces.  The toxic endpoint distance is 0.5 miles.
 
 
 
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION
 
     The E & J Gallo Winery employs RETA- trained refrigeration mechanics, supported by engineering staff.  The refrigeration system is maintained through a scheduled preventative maintenance program based upon standard industry practices. Employees required to operate ammonia refrigeration equipment receive training specific to their assigned duties. 
 
 
 
EMERGENCY RESPONSE
 
     In the event of a reportable chemical release, notifications will be made to the appropriate agencies including the Fresno County Department of Health Services, the State Office of Emergency Services (as directed by the Fresno County CUPA), and the Federal National Response Center (as appropriate). 
 
     Gallo management and members of the in-house emergency response team will respond to the emergency and work with public emergency response personnel in mitigating the problem.  
 
 
 
MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
 
     The Management of Change Procedure will require evaluation of new construction and modifications to existing ammonia systems to determine the likelihood of an effect on ammonia safety.  Changes expected to have a significant safety effect on quantity, systems, or procedures will be referred to the appropriate Risk Management Program team for further study. 
 
 
 
COMPLIANCE AUDITS
 
     E & J Gallo Winery will perform Risk Management Program compliance audits.  Th

e specific items in the Risk Management Plan will be re-examined and compliance documented.  The team reviewing these systems will consist of personnel from Engineering, Instrumentation, Maintenance, and Operations or will be conducted by a third party.  
 
 
 
 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 
 
     Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOPS) of the ammonia systems were conducted in July 16, 2009.  As a result of the study, numerous improvements have been identified. The recommendations will be followed by a Risk Management Program/Process Safety Management steering committee which includes the senior managers on site.  This steering committee will assign ownership of all recommendations and will meet on a quarterly basis to evaluate progress.
 
     These recommendations address such subjects as improved training, standard operating procedures, the value and feasibility of non-destructive testing, increased vehicle barricading, improved alarm and control systems, audits, checklists, upgraded hardware, improved interlocks, management of change, use of personal protective equipment, etc.
 
 
 
PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS 
 
     The E & J Gallo Winery performed process hazard analyses of the ammonia systems. The latest process hazard analysis (PHA) was started July 16, 2009.  Using PHAWorks 5 software by PrimeTech, five employees met one time per week for several hours per session to review the ammonia systems.  
 
     The five member team conducting the PHAs included a refrigeration mechanic, refrigeration operator/Team Leader, a Corporate Safety and Health Manager extensively trained in PHA methodology and refrigeration systems, a site Safety and Health Specialist, and the site Environmental Coordinator/Team Leader.  In total, approximately 200 man-hours have been spent on the ammonia PHAs when they are completed.
 
     After the PHAs are completed, the recommendations will be followed up by a Risk Management Program/Process Safety Management steering committee whic

h includes the senior managers on site.  This steering committee will assign ownership of all recommendations and will meet on a quarterly basis to evaluate progress.
 
 
     Process flow diagrams were used to develop the process sections used to evaluate the systems.  
 

Ammonia Refrigeration                          Plant Ammonia Systems
 
A   Receivers, tanks, vessels                 M   Plant ammonia receiver, piping, valves
B   Liquid manifolds and valves               N   Distillery scrubbing system
C   Chiller                                   O   Ion exchange wastewater pH control
                                                  system
D   Float Column                              P   Pumps
E   Back pressure regulator                   X   Ammonium hydroxide system
F   Compressors                               Y   Wastewater sump pH control system
G   Separators                                Z   Evaporator hot well
H   Condenser
I     Piping and tubing
J    Electrical Systems
 
 
 
     The following parameters were selected for each process section:
 
a.   Flow                                    d.   Quantity/Level
b.   Pressure                                e.   Material composition
c.   Temperature
 

     Additional parameters were considered where appropriate, including:
 
h.   Electrical systems
l.     Operational considerations
 

     The following guidewords were applied to the parameters as appropriate:
 
1.   No                                   10.   Drop
2.   Less                                 11.   As well as 
3.   More                                 12.   Rise of fall
4.   Restricted                           13.   Interrupted
5.   Restriction within                   14.   Empty
6.   Reverse                              15.   Foreign materials
7.   External Event                       16.   Leaking
8.   Suction                              17.   Ruptured
9.   Higher                               18.   Intermittent
 

     The combinat

ion of parameters and guidewords describe a possible deviation.  The HAZOPS team analyzed these deviations to determine possible causes, consequences, probability, severity, and safeguards.  It should be noted that many combinations reflect normal operating conditions, or conditions that present little or no risk.
 
     In addition, the HAZOPS team plans to tour the facility to inspect areas involved in the use or storage of these materials. Consideration will be given to external factors such as the location of traffic, personnel, equipment, or other processes in the vicinity, fire hazards, and weather.  
 
     Recommendations have been made in response to concerns raised during the HAZOPS process.  The meeting minutes, agendas, and records of the HAZOP studies are maintained in the main office of the Winery.
